"SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." The Congress finds that the Brown v. Board of Education decision was significant, the Little Rock Nine integration was a key example, and Central High School is renowned for its beauty. Central High School, a historic landmark, played a significant role in the civil rights movement by integrating public schools in the United States. It was recognized for its beauty and designated as a national historic landmark. The school's inclusion in the National Park System acknowledges its contribution to desegregation efforts. The Little Rock Central High School was designated as a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement and desegregation of public schools in the South. The purpose of this Act is to preserve and interpret the school's significance for present and future generations. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as a unit of the National Park System in Arkansas. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the site in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary will administer the historic site in accordance with relevant laws and may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies to further the purposes of the Act. The Secretary will coordinate with organizations and institutions for the purposes of the Act, prepare a general management plan within 2 years, and consult with the Little Rock School District to ensure educational use is not interfered with. The Secretary is authorized to acquire property for the historic site with consent of the owner, and must consult with the Little Rock School District to ensure educational use is not disrupted. SEC. 3. DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY. Within 2 years, the Secretary must conduct a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education. The study aims to identify significant sites and structures related to racial desegregation in education and propose new national historic landmarks. This study also provides opportunities for education and research. The Secretary will identify new national historic landmarks related to desegregation in public education and create a list of important sites. The theme study will also recommend ways to connect these sites for educational and research purposes, including collaborations with various entities to preserve and interpret key locations. The theme study on desegregation in public education will recommend opportunities for public education and research, as well as cooperative agreements with educational institutions and organizations. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with knowledgeable entities to ensure scholarly standards are met. The theme study will be part of the general management plan for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out this Act.
